entry.title: Re: Redirect navigation to extended â€œManage Central Purch...
entry.content:
We had a similar requirement and we solved this using authorizations. 

Use the same semantic object - action combination as the standard app, but the component points to the extended app in the tile + target mapping of your extended app.  In the role, only the new target mapping is added. 

This should allow you to open the app from other apps using cross app navigation, but will open the extended app since only this is present in the role.

entry.title: Credit Risk Analyzer: Limits Management - Money Market (Fixed Deposits) and Forex (Spots)
entry.content:
Credit Risk Analyzer helps to manage default risk of counterparties by tracking limits assigned to them on real time basis. This blog describes limits management for both Money Market (Fixed Deposits) and Forex (Spots).  

For limits management, following are essential configurational elements: Limit Types, Determination Procedure, Default Risk Rule, and Derivation of Risk Rule. Starting with necessary configurations, the blog will cover required cutover activities as well as relevant Fiori Apps, and SAP tables.

Configuration steps: -

Enablement of Credit Risk Analyzer starts with activation of necessary financial objects: -

  • IMG > TRM > Basic Analyzer Settings > Automatic Integration of Financial Objects in Transaction Master Data > Activate/Deactivate Automatic Integration of Financial Objects >
    • Money Market: Activate/Deactivate Financial Object Integration
    • Foreign Exchange: Activate/Deactivate Financial Object Integration

 

 

IMG > TRM > Credit Risk Analyzer > Basic Settings > Activate Integrated Default Risk Limit Check >

Configurations related to Determination Procedure and Default Risk Rule are very integral part for the proper tracking of default risk under Credit Risk Analyzer: -

IMG > TRM > Credit Risk Analyzer > Basic Settings > Definitions > Define Determination Procedures >

Determination Procedure for Fixed Deposits: -

Determination Procedure for Forex - Spots: -

Note:

  1. Forex Forward transactions will utilize credit risk limit only, whereas only Settlement Risk is applicable to Forex Spots  transactions.
  2. Irrespective of the transaction type (i.e., 101 - Spot, 102 - Forward and others) entered while creating a FX transaction, the system will treat the FX deal as FX Spot if the Value Date is within the number of spot days (configurable items), otherwise it is treated as FX Forward transaction.   

IMG > TRM > Credit Risk Analyzer > Basic Settings > Definitions > Define Default Risk Rule >

For Fixed Deposits: -

For Forex Spots: -

Now, the mapping of Determination Procedure and Default Risk Rule: -

Last and most important configuration node for Limit Management is Limit Types: -

IMG > TRM > Credit Risk Analyzer > Limit Management > Define Limit Types >

For Fixed Deposits: -

For Forex Spots: -

Under Assigned Limit Characteristics folder, we used Company Code and Business Partner, so that each counterparty can be assigned limit at the level of company code.

Cutover Activities: -

IMG > TRM > Credit Risk Analyzer > Basic Settings > Derive Default Risk Control Parameters >

This is derivation of Default Risk Rule for both the product types i.e., Fixed Deposits and Spots.

IMG > TRM > Basic Analyzer Settings > Automatic Integration of Financial Objects in Transaction Master Data > Customize Classic Derivation >

  • Money Market: Derive Default Risk Control Parameters for MM Transactions
  • Foreign Exchange: Derive Default Risk Control Parameters for Foreign Exchange

Similarly, for Forex Spots as well.

Fiori Apps: -

  • Manage Limits (TBL1)
  • Review Limit Utilizations (TBLB)
  • End-of-Day Processing (KLNACHT)

SAP tables: -

  • VTBLS â€“ Limits: Mapping Logical â€“ Physical Keys
  • VTBLV - Limits
  • VTBLIS â€“ Limit Utilization: Summarization

During cutover, we should first maintain / upload the limits of each of the counterparty, and then simulate the limits check during contract creation: -

I sincerely hope this blog covers Credit Risk Analyzer comprehensively from configuration to cutover. Open to your feedback and experience.

entry.title: Re: How to change the price condition which is overwritte...
entry.content: You must create variant condition keys using transaction VK30. You must create a condition type with flag 'variant cond' set. Etc. See also F1 help of that flag. You maintain the condition records for your new condition type with the condition key as a key field using VK11/12/13. See how it is done for VA00. In VC you create a multi-value reference chrematistic that refers to structure SDCOM-VKOND using CT04. Assign it to the class of your KMAT using CL02. Then use transaction PMEVC to create a procedure to set the condition key as value for the reference cstic and use the $SET_PRICING_FACTOR as described in online help. With that, VC hands it over to pricing, which uses it to find a condition records for the given key and applies the factor when calculating the condition value from the condition rate that was maintained in the condition record.

entry.title: Re: Maximum limit in the number of approvers in a workflo...
entry.content:
Hello!

There is no setting or hard stops for the number of approvers that can be assigned to workflow but best practice recommends limiting the approval steps so that items are processed efficiently and to avoid any bottlenecks in the process. 

Sometimes less is more. The more complex the workflow steps it will negatively impact timely approvals.

I hope this helps!

Thank you

Paddy Koltsaklis

entry.title: Re: Looking for Global Hierarchy CDS views / APIs keyword...
entry.content:
Good day @R_S2 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Manage Global Hierarchies, Using SAP S/4HANA Cloud Apps for SAP Analytics Cloud Integration, SAP HANA Core Data Services

Answer to question 1:

There are no released CDS views and no OData APIs for Global Hierarchies in public cloud. This is common in public cloud that some fragments are not delivered. To my knowledge, the only ones you can access are for financial statements and not for Global Hierarchies.

Answer to question 2:

Yes. Due to the public clouds clean-core principle, it is normal because Global Hierarchies are UI-only with no backend API exposure. Alternatively, I recommend exporting from UI, you can also consider building your custom hierarchy manually, use RPA or Datasphere (this will depend on if SAP releases hierarchy extension)

In summary, Manage Global Hierarchies app is delivered in the public cloud but without exposing any backend CDS views or APIs for reading the hierarchy. So, the ones you listed are not available. The current clean-core compliant alternatives include, exporting hierarchies from the app, reconstructing them manually in custom CDS, using SAP Build RPA or loading them into BTP/Datasphere.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Financial Statement Apps Show Old FSV Structure of Mi...
entry.content: After migrating an FSV to Global Hierarchies, some reporting apps, such as Balance Sheet/Income Statement and the Multidimensional version, may continue to display the old structure because these apps do not automatically consume all Global Hierarchy based FSVs. This behaviour is expected and app dependent rather than a migration issue. Please see KBA 3438291 in this regard.

entry.title: Re: Unable to authenticate backend system from SAP BAS vi...

The destination in BTP usually has technical user credentials provided. Check if the user in S4 system is active and the password has any issues. It could be that the technical user is locked because an incorrect password was used. 

This was the most common reason why I would see the destination have an authentication error in BAS.

entry.title: SAP Central Business Configuration: Activate Your SAP Business AI Features Centrally and Flexibly
entry.content:
Managing your SAP Business AI features is more straightforward than you might think: We offer a tailored view on AI features that matter to you, with the option to activate or deactivate them anytime.

You can simply log on to SAP Central Business Configuration, AI-assisted scoping and configuration services. Here, all the AI features relevant to you, depending on the SAP solutions youâ€™re running, are displayed centrally. There are two ways to go about the activation: Depending on the AI features in question, you can instantly activate them yourself or you can have them activated by creating a support case. The AI features for SAP Sustainability Control Tower are the first features enabled for instant activation. For those, and many more planned for the future, you wonâ€™t need to create a support case. Instead, you can activate or deactivate them directly via the UI, unleashing value in seconds.

 Screenshot of SAP Central Business Configuration, AI-assisted scoping and configuration services

This free-of-charge service is a game-changer for you as SAP cloud customers, providing you with the autonomy and flexibility to manage AI features according to your specific business needs anytime. This also aligns with our vision for SAP Central Business Configuration as the central scoping and configuration tool, not only allowing AI feature activation but also enabling you to take all your scoping decisions centrally and autonomously. Stay tuned for more!

For all other AI features, the system for now guides you seamlessly to create a support case and provides you with all the information needed to do so. To learn more about the current step-by-step process, please check out this video:

Video on how to activate and deactivate SAP Business AI features via support case

Did you like this blog? If so, please leave us a thumbs up at the top. Also, make sure to follow the SAP Central Business Configuration tag or follow this dedicated blog collection to stay up to date with the latest blog posts.

entry.title: Extracting/Splitting Json String in SAP HANA using Table Function(SQL)
entry.content:
Source Data : TABLE

JSON_STRING

IDJSON_STRING
1[{"code":"MI007","descr":"James Bond"}]
2[{"code":"MI007","descr":"James Bond"},{"code":"MI005","descr":"Max Well"}]
3[{"code":"MI007","descr":"James Bond"},{"code":"MI005","descr":"Max Well"},{"code":"MI004","descr":"Donald Trump"}]

ID 2 and 3 have multiple code and descr 

In order to split/ extract the Json string in such a way that,

The code and descr should be splitted/extracted for same ID's which results in multiple rows.

 

FUNCTION "XYZ_JSON" ( ) 

RETURNS TABLE (ID NVARCHAR(50),
               CODE_VALUE NVARCHAR(255),
               TEXT_VALUE NVARCHAR(255)
		       )

LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
SQL SECURITY DEFINER AS
BEGIN

 -- Create a temporary table to store the final results

 DECLARE result_table TABLE ( 
                   ID NVARCHAR(50),
                   CODE_VALUE NVARCHAR(255),
                   TEXT_VALUE NVARCHAR(255)
				   );

 -- Declare working variables

 DECLARE current_row_id INT; -- Holds the row ID for the current row

 DECLARE remaining_string NVARCHAR(5000); -- Holds the remaining string to process

 DECLARE code_match NVARCHAR(255); -- Stores the currently matched value

 DECLARE descr_match NVARCHAR(255);

 DECLARE i INT; -- Match occurrence counter

 DECLARE cursor input_sql for SELECT ID,JSON_STRING, OCCURRENCES_REGEXPR('code":"' IN "JSON_STRING" ) as occur_code
 FROM "TABLE/CAL.VIEW";

 -- Loop through each row of the input table

  FOR cur_row AS input_sql

     -- Replace this with your actual table name

     DO

     -- Initialize variables for processing the current row

      current_row_id := :cur_row.id; -- Current row ID

      remaining_string := :cur_row.json_string; -- Current row's string to process

      IF cur_row.occur_code = 0 OR cur_row.occur_code IS NULL THEN

           INSERT INTO :result_table VALUES (cur_row.id, cur_row.json_string, NULL);

      END IF;



        FOR i IN 1..cur_row.occur_code DO


           code_match := SUBSTRING_REGEXPR('code":"([^"]*)"' IN remaining_string OCCURRENCE i GROUP 1);

           descr_match := SUBSTRING_REGEXPR('descr":"([^"]*)"' IN remaining_string OCCURRENCE i GROUP 1);

          -- Check if a match is found


           IF code_match IS NOT NULL THEN

                -- Add the match to the result table

                INSERT INTO :result_table VALUES (current_row_id, code_match, descr_match);

              ELSE

                -- Exit the loop when no more matches are found

                 BREAK;

           END IF;

        END FOR;

   END FOR;

    -- Output the final results

 return SELECT * FROM :result_table;

END;

Calling the table function.

select * from "XYZ_JSON"();

 

IDCODE_VALUETEXT_VALUE
1MI007James Bond
2MI007James Bond
2MI005Max Well
3MI007James Bond 
3MI005Max Well
3MI004Donald Trump

entry.title: Re: error by exection TPM10
entry.content:
TPM_EDIT; Change then Cash Flow tab shift display mode from 'Edit' to 'Reverse' by clicking a screen icon, system will show the flows which are posted and can be reversed. Right click the flow which you want to reverse and select option "reverse" and save the screen. Note the flow will marked with reversed indicator in cashflow tab.

Run TPM10 for those flows to reverse the posting entries and then you can correct the data. Here you are not reversing the transaction but reversing only the flows.

entry.title: Re: ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of clean core ABAP development
entry.content:
Hi @OlgaDolinskaja 

We have configured our 2511 BTP Central system to run Clean Core analysis on a remote 758 system using the new ABAP_CLEAN_CORE_DEVELOPMENT ATC variant. When reviewing this variant, we noticed that it includes a significant number of additional checks on top of the Clean Core checks.

Our understanding is that the none Clean Core checks in this variant are there to ensure high code quality by adhering to best practices.

Since our current objective is to achieve Level C Clean Core certification, we are considering creating a Z copy of ABAP_CLEAN_CORE_DEVELOPMENT that contains only the Clean Core relevant checks. Our rationale is that the other checks will be resolved through our normal BAU processes over time.

Can you please confirm whether our assumption is correct, ie in order to achieve Level C Clean Core certification, we only need to run the Clean Core checks in Variant ABAP_CLEAN_CORE_DEVELOPMENT and ensure there are 0 errors?

entry.title: Re: Output Parameters for Handling Unit Label Printing in...
entry.content:
Hello,

The following documentation shows the fields you can use in the Output Parameter Determination app for the application type Handling Unit: Sources of Condition Parameters Used in Output Parameter Determination | SAP Help Portal.

You can use those fields for defining your business rules. If a field is not directly visible in the rule definition table for a certain step, you can add them in the Table Settings as additional columns. For general information about the output management business rules for Handling Unit Management, see: Output Management for Handling Unit Management | SAP Help Portal.

However, if I know it correctly, it is in general not possible to define a printer in the business rules if you use EXTOM as the output channel. Your external output management system would need to determine the printer. 

For general information about the EXTOM channel, see EXTOM Channel | SAP Help Portal.

Best regards,
Tanja

entry.title: Re: Missing "Payment details" tag in XML Facturae (public...
entry.content:
Good day @MatiasGarciaKPS 

Thank you for your question.

In addition to the link @HenrikeGrtecke provided , the public cloud only displays <PaymentDetails> node in Spanish FACe XML if you have fully maintained the supplierâ€™s bank data and the payment method requires bank details. Due to public cloudâ€™s clean-core principle, the system suppresses tags unless you have provided all required data. I suggest you verifying your supplier IBAN, default bank account, payment method configuration and your mapping version in Define eDocuments. If those are correct, then rebuild the eDocument.

If PaymentsDetails is still missing,

  1. Check and correct your Master data. This often solves the problem as inconsistencies in master data are often the source.
  2. You can consider enabling PaymentDetails through mapping enhancement (use Define eDocument mapping to extend mapping by adding a conditional rule e.g., if supplier bank exists, then generate PaymentDetails. Map: IBAN, BranchCode and BankName. This is compliant with the public cloud clean-core principle.
  3. Another option is to use company code bank instead (this alternative is also allowed by Spain) because some FACe scenarios accept the companyâ€™s receiving bank instead of Supplierâ€™s. You can switch to company code bank in mapping.
  4. If your system is missing the Payment details node completely, I suggest you raise an incident.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Spain Facturae, Code Flow When XML is Submitted from the eDocument Cockpit

Creating Electronic Document for Sales Billing Documents for Public Entities - Web Service

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Aufbau einer Key-User-Community im SAP S/4HANA-Projekt bei Aalberts hydronic flow control
entry.content:
Kathleen Regener berichtet Ã¼ber den Aufbau einer Key-User-Community in einem internationalen S/4HANA-Projekt. Die zentrale Erkenntnis: Eine Community braucht mehr als nur Infrastruktur â€“ sie braucht den richtigen Zeitpunkt, aktive Moderation und Key-User, die etwas Greifbares haben, um sich beteiligen zu kÃ¶nnen.

Ãœber das Projekt und die Ausgangssituation

Kathleen Regener, PMO und Lead Change Management bei Aalberts hydronic flow control, berichtete in der SAP Training und Change Kaffee-Ecke Ã¼ber den Aufbau einer Key-User-Community im Rahmen der konzernweiten S/4HANA-Transformation. Das Unternehmen bietet ganzheitliche LÃ¶sungen fÃ¼r Heiz-, KÃ¼hl- und SanitÃ¤rsysteme in GebÃ¤uden an. Das Projekt umfasst die AblÃ¶sung von 6 verschiedenen ERP-Systemen fÃ¼r insgesamt 800 Enduser.

Die Besonderheit: Die Key-User wurden nicht ausgewÃ¤hlt, sondern konnten sich fÃ¼r das Projekt bewerben. Am Ende konnten Ã¼ber 100 motivierte Key-User gewonnen werden, die die Ã„nderungen mittragen wollten. Diese wurden in lokale Key-User und Power User aufgeteilt. Die lokalen Key-User waren die Ansprechpartner fÃ¼r das Projektteam und wurden fÃ¼r ihre Rolle freigestellt. Die Power User unterstÃ¼tzten nach verfÃ¼gbarer Zeit.

Struktur der Key-User-Community

Das Projektteam bestand aus Domain Process Ownern (DPOs), Technical Process Ownern (TPOs) und den Key-Usern. FÃ¼r die Global Template Phase wurden zusÃ¤tzlich Global Key-User aus den Niederlanden, Deutschland und Frankreich eingebunden, die in die Workstreams Warehouse, Sales, Production, Supply Chain und Finance aufgeteilt waren.

Abbildung 1: Struktur des Projektteams mit DPOs, TPOs, Key-Usern (Global und lokal) und Power Usern

Projektphasen und Rollout-Strategie

Nach der Template-Phase wurden die Global Key-User zu lokalen Key-Usern und im ersten Rollout in den Niederlanden und UK eingesetzt. Die Ã¼brigen Key-User gingen in eine Projektpause.

Diese Projektpause warf zentrale Fragen auf:

  • Wie bleibt man mit allen in Kontakt?
  • Wie kÃ¶nnen die Key-User zu einem Team zusammenwachsen?
  • Wie kÃ¶nnen wir sicherstellen, dass wir alle relevanten Informationen mit allen teilen?
  • Wie teilt man Lessons Learned aus den einzelnen Waves?

Aufbau der Community-Infrastruktur

Die Entscheidung fiel auf den Aufbau einer Teams-basierten Community mit verschiedenen KanÃ¤len. Der Start erfolgte mit einem offiziellen Kick-Off fÃ¼r alle Key-User. Es wurde eine Hausordnung erstellt, die das Verhalten in der Community regelte. Die Key-User erhielten eine Teams-Schulung, um die Umgebung optimal nutzen zu kÃ¶nnen.

Inhalte der Key-User-Community

Die Community bot ein umfassendes Angebot:

Workshop-Unterlagen:

  • Stressmanagement
  • Umgang mit WiderstÃ¤nden
  • Train-the-Trainer-Unterlagen

Dokumentationen:

  • Quick Reference Cards
  • Projekt- und SAP-Glossar
  • FAQ zu Projekt und S/4HANA
  • Rollenbeschreibungen

Kommunikation und Austausch:

  • Raum fÃ¼r Fragen
  • Raum fÃ¼r Erfolgsstories
  • Raum fÃ¼r Lessons Learned
  • Projektinformationen und Timeline
  • Zentraler Meeting Hub
  • RegelmÃ¤ÃŸige Communication Starter

Ein Feedback-Channel wurde eingerichtet. Fragen wurden so beantwortet, dass die Antworten fÃ¼r alle Key-User sinnvoll nutzbar waren und im gesamten Team geteilt wurden.

Herausforderungen in der Praxis

Trotz der umfassender Vorbereitung gestaltete sich der Start schwierig. Die Reaktionen auf Communication Starter beschrÃ¤nkten sich meist auf ein Daumen-hoch. Nach einem halben Jahr lautete das Fazit: Wir hatten keine Community, sondern ein Publikum. Die Informationen wurden aufgenommen, aber es fand keine wirkliche Interaktion statt.

Die neun zentralen Herausforderungen

Kathleen identifizierte neun konkrete Herausforderungen:

  • Keine Reaktionen der Key-User an uns als Change Management
  • Doppelrolle (Projekt und TagesgeschÃ¤ft) fÃ¼hrte zu Zeitproblemen bei Key Usern
  • Die Community hat nicht gelebt - es gab keine echte Interaktion
  • Unsicherheit beim Teilen: Key-User aus Wave 1 wussten nicht, was sie mit anderen Key-Usern teilen kÃ¶nnen
  • Fehlende Fragestellung: Key-User aus inaktiven Waves wussten nicht, was sie fragen kÃ¶nnen
  • Projektinformationen konnten nicht geteilt werden, da teilweise noch keine Entscheidungen getroffen waren oder das System noch nicht fertig war
  • RegelmÃ¤ÃŸige Check-Ins wurden nicht genutzt, da sich Key-User noch nicht vom Projekt betroffen fÃ¼hlten
  • Unterschiedliches Onboarding von Key-Usern und Power Usern
  • Geringe Teilnahmequote an Umfragen

Die zentrale Erkenntnis war: Der Zeitpunkt fÃ¼r den Aufbau der Community war falsch gewÃ¤hlt.

Lessons Learned und Anpassungen

Eine Umfrage zeigte, dass die Key-User Beispiele, Tipps und Best Practices wollten, ihnen aber nicht bewusst war, dass sie selbst Input liefern mÃ¼ssten. Das Selbstbewusstsein, selbst zur Community beitragen zu kÃ¶nnen, fehlte.

Konkrete Anpassungen in Wave 2

Abbildung: Change Management Lessons Learned und implementierte Verbesserungen

Das Change Management implementierte acht zentrale Verbesserungen:

  1. Onboarding-Phase und Toolkit fÃ¼r Key-User der nÃ¤chsten Wave
  • Alle betroffenen lokalen Key-User und Power User wurden zum Kick-Off eingeladen
  • GebÃ¼ndelte Informationen in Landessprache
  • Hausaufgaben und Systemzugriff fÃ¼r die Vorbereitungsphase
  1. Statt Umfragen fÃ¼r Lessons Learned â†’ feste Termine fÃ¼r Feedback
  • Gezielte Fragen in persÃ¶nlichen Terminen
  • Mehr direktes Feedback
  1. ErhÃ¶hung der Kommunikationsfrequenz
  • Zwei bis drei Communication Starter pro Woche
  • Mehr Bewegung in der Community
  1. Auf Wunsch: Aufnahme der DPOs und TPOs
  • Mehr Sicherheit fÃ¼r Key-User
  • Direkter Zugang zu EntscheidungstrÃ¤gern
  1. Bi-weekly Community Meeting â†’ monatliches Meeting
  • Nur fÃ¼r Key-User der aktuellen Wave
  • In Landessprache
  • Mit Vorab-Fragen Ã¼ber den Feedback-Kanal
  1. EinfÃ¼hrung des Projekt-Glossars
  • Besseres VerstÃ¤ndnis fÃ¼r pausierte Key-User
  • Einheitliche Sprache im Projekt
  1. Anpassung/Trennung der einzelnen Umfragen
  • Wave-bezogene Umfragen
  • Angepasst an die jeweilige Projektphase
  1. Buddy-System fÃ¼r Key-User aus Wave 1 und 2
  • Erfahrene Key-User unterstÃ¼tzen neue Key-User
  • Ãœber Teams-Tag-Funktion organisiert
  • Austausch bleibt sichtbar fÃ¼r andere

Schulung und Training

Die Key-User wurden in zwei Schienen geschult: im Systembereich und vom Change Management im Bereich Trainingsgestaltung, Umgang mit WiderstÃ¤nden und Umgang mit Endusern. Die Schulungsunterlagen waren Aufgabe der Key-User, wurden aber von den DPOs reviewed. Enduser wurden einbezogen, um zu prÃ¼fen, ob das Level fÃ¼r gute Schulungen erreicht wurde.

Die Enduser-Trainings werden von den Key-Usern geplant und durchgefÃ¼hrt. Die Key-User stehen nach dem Go-Live als Hypercare-Support zur VerfÃ¼gung und sind danach erste Ansprechpartner fÃ¼r die Enduser. Die Trainingsunterlagen werden auf einer Enduser-SharePoint-Seite fÃ¼r alle zugÃ¤nglich abgelegt und sind Ã¼ber SAP Enable Now nachtrÃ¤glich verfÃ¼gbar.

Bei der Trainingsplanung durften die Key-User die GruppengrÃ¶ÃŸe selbst festlegen, was zu mehr Wohlbefinden fÃ¼hrte. Es wurden Dry Runs veranstaltet, bei denen die Key-User ihre Classroom-Trainings vor dem Projektteam vorfÃ¼hren und Feedback erhalten konnten. Templates wurden bereitgestellt, um die Key-User zu entlasten.

Rolle des Change Managements

Das Change Management wurde erst mit diesem Projekt aufgebaut. Intern lastet die Arbeit auf einer Person (=Kathleen), unterstÃ¼tzt von drei Personen eines Implementierungspartners. Ein Community Lead aus den Key-Usern war geplant, konnte aber aufgrund von Zeitmangel nicht umgesetzt werden. Das Change Management Ã¼bernahm daher wieder die Moderation.

Die Kommunikation an das Management war wichtig, um sicherzustellen, dass die Key-User Zeit fÃ¼r ihre Projektarbeit bekommen und nicht mit 150 Prozent belastet werden. Das Change Management nutzte SAP Enable Now fÃ¼r die Erstellung von Lernpfaden fÃ¼r neue Kollegen um das Onboarding optimal vorzubereiten.

Erkenntnisse aus der Diskussion in der Community Session

Die Teilnehmenden an der Session teilten zahlreiche eigene Erfahrungen. HÃ¤ufig genannte Herausforderungen waren Ãœberlastung der Key-User, Sprachbarrieren, regionale Arbeitsweisen, uneinheitliche Anforderungen und fehlende Ressourcen.

Was funktioniert in der Praxis?

Formate fÃ¼r erfolgreiche Communities:

  • PrÃ¤senztreffen und direkter Austausch
  • Zwei Stunden Treffen alle zwei Wochen mit der Projektleitung
  • Zweimal monatlich eine Stunde via Teams
  • Subgruppen nach Lokationen
  • RegelmÃ¤ÃŸige Calls mit fester Agenda
  • Moderierte Online-Plattformen
  • Informelle Treffen wie Kaffeeroulette

UnterstÃ¼tzungsmaÃŸnahmen:

  • Train-the-Trainer-Seminare
  • Change-Management-Trainings
  • Konfliktmanagement-Training
  • Ambassador-Netzwerke
  • Templates fÃ¼r Schulungsunterlagen
  • Dry Runs mit Feedback
  • Tandem-AnsÃ¤tze bei ersten Schulungen
  • ZusÃ¤tzliche Testressourcen

Engagement fÃ¶rdern â€“ denn Engagement ist eine der groÃŸen Herausforderungen in Communities:

  • Niedrigschwellige Formate wie Polls
  • Belohnungen fÃ¼r Key-User wie Special Events
  • In manchen FÃ¤llen monetÃ¤re Anreize
  • Lessons-Learned-Sessions
  • Gemeinsame Retrospektiven
  • Social Events â€“ feiern von Erfolgen

Innovative AnsÃ¤tze:

  • Kaffeeroulette Ã¼ber Teams: Zwei bis drei User werden per Zufall fÃ¼r eine Viertelstunde zusammengefÃ¼hrt
  • Networking Lunch mit Matching nach Interessen
  • ThemenvorschlÃ¤ge fÃ¼r informelle Treffen

Konkrete Tipps fÃ¼r die Praxis von Key-User Netzwerken

Auch wenn es nun evtl. Dopplungen gibt versuche ich hier nochmals Tips von Kathleen sowie den vielen Community Teilnehmenden hier aufzufÃ¼hren. 

Timing und Planung

Timing beachten: Den richtigen Zeitpunkt fÃ¼r den Community-Start wÃ¤hlen. Key-User brauchen etwas Greifbares, um sich beteiligen zu kÃ¶nnen.

Einheitliches Onboarding: Alle Key-User-Gruppen von Anfang an gleich abholen, um unterschiedliche WissensstÃ¤nde zu vermeiden.

Wave-bezogene Planung: Umfragen und Meetings an die jeweilige Projektphase anpassen.

Kommunikation und Moderation

Aktive Moderation: Communities brauchen aktive Moderation und regelmÃ¤ÃŸige Impulse. Communication Starter allein reichen nicht.

Kommunikationsfrequenz erhÃ¶hen: Zwei bis drei Impulse pro Woche setzen, um Bewegung in die Community zu bringen.

Management einbinden: FÃ¼hrungskrÃ¤fte Ã¼ber den Zeitbedarf der Key-User informieren.

Sprache und VerstÃ¤ndnis

Sprache anpassen: Bei internationalen Projekten Meetings und Unterlagen in Landessprache anbieten.

Technische Hilfsmittel nutzen: MS Teams mit Co-Pilot und Teams Professional fÃ¼r Ãœbersetzungen nutzen.

Glossar erstellen: Sicherstellen, dass alle in einer Sprache sprechen durch ein Projekt-Glossar.

Entlastung und UnterstÃ¼tzung

Entlastung schaffen: Key-User durch Templates, Dry Runs, Tandem-AnsÃ¤tze und zusÃ¤tzliche Ressourcen (z.B. beim Testen) aktiv unterstÃ¼tzen.

Didaktische UnterstÃ¼tzung: Power User oder Autoren unterstÃ¼tzen bei der Unterlagenerstellung.

Backfill organisieren: Neue Mitarbeitende einstellen oder interne Umverteilung fÃ¼r Daily Business.

Formate und Tools

PrÃ¤senz ermÃ¶glichen: Wo mÃ¶glich, PrÃ¤senztreffen oder zumindest regelmÃ¤ÃŸige Online-Meetings mit fester Agenda organisieren.

Buddy-Systeme nutzen: Erfahrene Key-User mit neuen Key-Usern vernetzen.

Tool-Wahl: AbhÃ¤ngig von Kommunikationsgewohnheiten im Unternehmen (Teams, Slack, SharePoint).

Subgruppen bilden: Nach Lokationen, Workstreams oder Waves organisieren.

Erwartungsmanagement

Erwartungen managen: Nicht erwarten, dass alle aktiv mitmachen. In Communities sind oft nur ein bis zwei Prozent wirklich aktiv.

Publikum vs. Community: Verstehen, dass Community-Bildung Zeit braucht.

Zusammenfassung

Der Aufbau einer Key-User-Community in einem internationalen S/4HANA-Projekt ist komplex und braucht Zeit. Die initiale Infrastruktur allein reicht nicht aus. Key-User befinden sich in einer Doppelrolle zwischen Daily Business und Projekt und brauchen aktive UnterstÃ¼tzung, klare Strukturen und das GefÃ¼hl, nicht allein zu sein.

Entscheidend ist, Key-User nicht zu Ã¼berfordern, sondern durch Templates, Schulungen und Tandem-AnsÃ¤tze zu entlasten. Sprachbarrieren und unterschiedliche WissensstÃ¤nde sollten aktiv adressiert werden. Der richtige Zeitpunkt fÃ¼r den Community-Start ist wichtig. Key-User brauchen etwas Konkretes, um sich beteiligen zu kÃ¶nnen.

Die Anpassungen in Wave 2 zeigten Wirkung: einheitliches Onboarding, hÃ¶here Kommunikationsfrequenz, Meetings in Landessprache, Buddy-Systeme und die Einbindung der DPOs und TPOs.

Change Management ist kein Nice-to-have, sondern essenziell fÃ¼r den Projekterfolg. Die Erkenntnis, dass viele Herausforderungen trotz unterschiedlicher Branchen Ã¤hnlich sind, zeigt uns auch wieder den Wert des Austauschs in der Community.

WeiterfÃ¼hrende Links und Ressourcen

SAP Community

  • SAP Training and Change Management Community
  • Dokumentation der Kaffee-Ecke Sessions und nÃ¤chster Termin

Kommende Sessions

  • Walk Me Praxisbeispiel - Webinar mit Stada (12/2025) / Walk Me Learning Arc - Infosession zur Learning Komponente (Januar 2026) / Enable Now zu Walk Me Transition - Roundtable (Februar 2026) â€“ Infos und Anmeldung hier
  • Kaffee-Ecke â€“ Change & Training Retrospektive 2025/ Ausblick 2026 - 18.12.2025

Ãœber die Kaffee-Ecke: Die SAP Training and Change Management Kaffee-Ecke ist eine monatliche Community Session, die jeden dritten Donnerstag im Monat stattfindet. Sie bietet Raum fÃ¼r Austausch, Good Practices und Lessons Learned rund um Training, Learning und Change Management in SAP-Projekten.

Bei Interesse an einem Impuls in kommenden Sessions oder Fragen zur Community meldet Euch gerne.

entry.title: Implementing reliable versioning in SAP HANA using SQL triggers
entry.content:
Recently I worked on data versioning and thought it could be interesting for someone else ðŸ˜ŠWhether you are tracking configuration changes, business rules, pricing tables, or workflow definitions, versioning ensures that updates are auditable, deterministic, and consistent. 

In this post, I'm going to share my thoughts how to implement versioning with statement-level triggers, solve typical challenges, and ensure version increments occur exactly once per relevant change.

I implemented versioning at the database level using SQL triggers, ensuring changes are tracked automatically and consistently. In this blog post Iâ€™m going to simplify the business versioning logic, so we can concentrate as only on the technical part. Furthermore I used HANA system versioning tables, but it is out of the scope in this post. Please be aware that this is just a small part of the real use case.

Use Case Overview

Imagine we have two tables:

  1. Entity A: Stores entity A metadata including its version. Each A_id column has a â€œversionâ€ column.
  2. Entity B: Stores entity B entries that reference a A_id. 

Whenever new rows are inserted into the table B, the corresponding entity Aâ€™s version must be incremented. This ensures that any change in usage of a rule automatically updates its version. 

Requirements

  • Insert/Update N rows into Entity B with the same A_id at once â†’ entity A version increments once, not N times.
  • Insert rows into Entity B with different A_ids â†’ each entity A version should increment once.

I implemented a statement-level trigger combined with temporary transaction-scoped tables.

Table Setup

CREATE TABLE "A" (
a_id NVARCHAR(10),
version INT
);
CREATE TABLE "B" (
b_id NVARCHAR(10),
a_id NVARCHAR(10),
description NVARCHAR(100)
);

To ensure that versions will be incremented once per transaction, two help tables are needed. We are going to track which a_ids have already been processed using:

CREATE GLOBAL TEMPORARY TABLE TMP_A_PROCESSED (
a_id NVARCHAR(10)
) ON COMMIT DELETE ROWS;

CREATE TABLE TMP_A_NEW (
a_id NVARCHAR(10)
);

The first table remembers which a_ids have already been incremented in the current transaction. The second table collects a_ids inserted by the current statement. 

Next we will need a versioning trigger. 

CREATE TRIGGER UPDATE_VERSION
AFTER INSERT OR UPDATE
ON B
REFERENCING NEW TABLE NEW_ROWS 
FOR EACH STATEMENT
BEGIN
INSERT INTO TMP_A_NEW (SELECT DISTINCT a_id FROM :new_rows
WHERE a_id NOT IN (SELECT DISTINCT a_id FROM TMP_A_PROCESSED));
UPDATE A t
SET "VERSION" = "VERISON" + 1
WHERE t.a_id IN (SELECT a_id FROM TMP_A_NEW);
INSERT INTO TMP_A_PROCESSED (SELECT DISTINCT a_id FROM TMP_A_NEW);
DELETE FROM TMP_A_NEW;
END;

Do not forget to turn off autocommit or wrap your inserts/updates in a procedure! TMP_A_NEW table can be defined as a global temporary table too. It is even better, so you will avoid data deletion inside a trigger.

This example can be extended by adding more tables where the versions will be increased in a chain. 

Conclusion

Implementing versioning logic using SAP HANA SQL triggers offers a robust and automatic way to ensure data consistency across related tables.

The provided example should be considered only as my personal experience.

entry.title: Transforming Finance Services with SAP Enterprise Service Management
entry.content:
Why Payment Advice Processing Reveals So Much About Todayâ€™s Finance Processes

In nearly every company, the process looks similar:

A customer sends a payment advice â€” typically a PDF attached to a short email. The document contains key information for Cash Application, Open Items Clearing, or Accounts Receivable. It may be incomplete, formatted differently every time, or ambiguous â€” and someone experienced needs to interpret it.

What looks trivial at first is actually one of the most time-consuming daily tasks in global Finance organizations. Why?

  • Shared mailboxes do not support routing, workload distribution, or SLAs.

  • PDF content must be manually read, retyped, and reconciled.

  • Agents jump between email, PDF, and S/4HANA to search for relevant data.

  • Clarifications happen via email with no link to the original request.

  • Decisions are often not documented â€” a nightmare for Audit & Compliance.

  • Global teams struggle with handovers, time zones, and missing context.

In other words:
The highest effort sits exactly where ERP systems have no visibility â€” outside their structured world.

And this is exactly the part ESM digitizes.

 

How ESM Reimagines Payment Advice Processing

With ESM, a Payment Advice is no longer â€œjust a PDF.â€ It becomes a structured service request â€” part of an orchestrated end-to-end process.

From Email Chaos to a Structured Intake

ESM automatically identifies that an inbound email contains a Payment Advice, creates a Case, and stores all messages, attachments, and follow-ups in one place.

From PDFs to Extracted, Usable Data

Document Extraction reads PDF content, extracts key fields, and maps them to the right data points. Manual typing, searching, and interpretation shrink dramatically.

From System Hopping to Embedded S/4HANA Insight

Agents see relevant S/4HANA information directly inside the case â€” open items, payment data, business partner context. No more switching between systems.

From Unclear Responsibilities to Rule-Based Routing

Cases are routed automatically based on customer, company code, region, or priority. Perfect for scaling global teams.

From Isolated Decisions to Full Auditability

Every communication, extracted value, edit, decision, and routing step is automatically documented â€” a major step forward for compliance and governance.

 

The Best Part: This End-to-End Scenario Is Surprisingly Fast to Build

A fully functional Payment Advice process in ESM requires only:

  • a defined Case Type,

  • email inbound configuration,

  • PDF extraction via Document Information Extraction,

  • a Business Document structure,

  • and a Mashup for SAP S/4HANA context.

In many projects, the first fully working version is live within days â€” not months.
And it is more than a proof of concept. It is a productive, high-value, easy-to-use process that requires minimal custom logic and is immediately usable by Finance teams.

Because payment advices are standardized but formatted differently, this process is the perfect example of how ESM reduces complexity and automates repetitive work.

 

What the Process Looks Like in Daily Operations

Instead of opening a shared inbox, agents start their day with a clean case list in ESM.
New Payment Advices appear automatically â€” categorized, analyzed, and prioritized.

Each case shows:

  • all original emails,

  • the extracted PDF content,

  • relevant S/4HANA context embedded directly in the UI,

  • metadata and suggested next actions,

  • and full history & communication.

Agents respond to customers directly from the case.
Internal clarifications happen in the same interface.
Routing to AR, AP, Treasury, or regional teams is seamless and fully traceable.

A previously fragmented, manual process suddenly has a clear, consistent flow.

 

The Real Impact: A Small Use Case With Huge Value

Companies that implemented ESM for Payment Advice Processing report:

  • significantly reduced manual effort,

  • faster processing times,

  • higher data quality,

  • fewer customer inquiries,

  • fewer errors,

  • improved auditability,

  • clear SLA-driven operations,

  • and far better visibility for management.

A process once considered â€œtoo smallâ€ or â€œtoo document-heavyâ€ for digitalization becomes a scalable, automated, high-quality service â€” simply by structuring the previously unstructured.

Payment Advice Processing is more than a use case.
It is a proof point for how Finance organizations can transform when they digitize the steps around their core ERP processes, not just the ones inside them.

 

Conclusion: ESM Is the Missing Piece in Modern Finance Operations

SAP Enterprise Service Management brings Finance service processes to the same maturity level as core S/4HANA transactions.
It delivers structure, transparency, speed, and governance exactly where they have been missing the most.

Payment Advice Processing demonstrates just how quickly this transformation is achievable â€” and how obvious the benefits are for Finance teams, customers, and the entire organization.

For many companies, this use case is the moment they realize:

ESM is not an add-on.
ESM is the new foundation for service-driven Finance processes.

entry.title: Re: SCORM Upload Failure to SuccessFactors LMS
entry.content:
- Make sure you are following the steps for SCORM publishing to SF as shown in https://enable-now.sap.com > Component Tutorials > Producer > Publishing/Export > slides 5 through 7. Also in me.sap.com, the Knowledge Base Articles (KBAs or SAP Notes) 2473984 and 2902368 are helpful in knowing how to set your Publish settings for SCORM output for SuccessFactors. There may be other KBAs that are relevant but I use these a lot. 
- If you're publishing directly from Producer into SuccessFactors, you have to select the Type as SAP SuccessFactors Learning, and fill out the login info for SF when it prompts you. If you're publishing a straight SCORM package for later upload into SF, then your Type is correct. 
- It's not clear from your question where the error occurs - as you generate the SCORM zipfile from Producer, or as you upload it into SuccessFactors. I didn't find any KBAs in me.sap.com that mention that error in either SEN or in SF, but it smells like it's an SF error. Check your permissions in SF - maybe you don't have permission to upload a SCORM zipfile, or you haven't made a place for it to reside in SF. 
- My personal experience is that (a.) you should never select the Multifile checkboxes during publishing, because it makes the book page templates in the SCORM package unreadable/inaccessible so your slide backgrounds do not display, and (b.) you want to make sure that the Playback settings you are using actually specify SCORM as the tracking mechanism. That's why most people have at least two Playback Settings groups - one for Manager tracking, and one for SCORM tracking. If you don't have the SCORM settings set within your Playback Settings that you use to publish the SCORM package, it won't track in the LMS. 

Those are the pitfalls I see from your screenshot of your Publish settings. Also, your SuccessFactors may have a size limit for the SCORM zipfile. My current customer's size limit is 250MB. This thread in the SAP Community discusses how to change it in SF. Solved: SCORM file size - SAP Community

@patrick_weber11, Thank you for sharing your detailed feedback and concerns regarding the SAP Solution Architect (P_BTPA) certification experience with the AI-based roleplay. Given the issues you described it is important that these are formally investigated. I recommend that you open a support case or ticket with the SAP Certification or Learning support team to ensure your attempts and results are reviewed and any technical problems are addressed.

When submitting your case, please include:

Thank you again for bringing this to attention - your feedback is valuable for improving the certification experience for everyone.

entry.title: Collaborative Draft with 3 Layers
entry.content:
Hi,

I have my business object developed in RAP with three layers: the base layer R_ (managed implementation), the interface layer I_ (interface) and the consumption lauer C_ (projection). Now I want to enable collaborative draft on C_ layer. I managed to enable collaborative draft on R_ layer by adding draft query to the draft table, action Share and statement on the top. I also enabled collaborative draft on I_ layer with "use collaborative draft;" + action Share. This does not cause any issues. But when I try to do the same thing on C_ layer, I get this error message:

To use "collaborative draft", base entity "I_<entity>" must define a "query" view for draft table "<draft table>".

I don't understand why this error is being raise. The base entity is not I_<entity> but R_<entity> where I have the query defined for the draft table. I got this error message when I did not have query defined on R_ level. But why is this being raised when activating C_ layer? Is it possible to enable collaborative draft when consumption layer is on top of interface layer?

I checked documentation for collaborative draft and it has the following message: "In case you have used an interface layer, you must also use the statement there." Based on this statement I assume that this should be supported. I also checked limitations of RAP but nothing is documented there regarding this. The SFLIGHT demo seems to be using only two layers.

Thanks

entry.title: Recording and slide deck of SAP on IBM i November webcast available for download
entry.content:
In our SAP on IBM i Webcast "A new paradigm for <sid>ADM - not just for IBM i 7.6", we introduced the new SETSAPUSR tool, which allows any user with enough authority to switch the current job run with user <sid>ADM. With the help of that tool, it is no longer necessary to share the <sid>ADM password between multiple administrators, and the interactive users can be protected by multi-factor authentication (MFA), which was newly introduced in IBM i 7.6.

As usual, the recording and slide deck of the webcast have been made available for download at the link https://ibm.biz/RadioSAPIBMi. You can find it there in the folder 2025, subfolder November 2025. If you missed the webcast or want to look at some aspects in more detail, you can look at the provided material and watch the recording at your own speed.

The link is accessible by invitation only. If you are not yet a user of Box, it will be necessary to register (free of charge) at Box with the company email address that will be used for the download. If you were registered for the webcast, you should already be authorized to it. If this is the first time you are trying to download material from this link, or if your access was lost for whatever reason, you can request access by sending an email to ibmsapevents@ibm.com and providing your name, company name, country, requested company email address (if different from sender), as well as the requested webcast date and title.

entry.title: Re: How to use Process Monitor
entry.content:
Process Monitor can be installed using the following command:

C:\> winget install Microsoft.Sysinternals.ProcessMonitor

Afterwards it can be started using the command: C:\> procmon

Install Location: %LOCALAPPDATA%\Microsoft\WinGet\Packages

entry.title: KSeF 2.0 Test Environment: Setup and Integrate Your System with the Cloud Edition
entry.content:
The original plan from the Poland authorities to introduce mandatory e-invoices through KSeF in 2024 was postponed. The delay was used to rebuild the infrastructure and launch KSeF 2.0. With that, some of the changes are reflected in the following:

  • The new KSeF 2.0 is not compatible with KSeF 1.0, meaning it significantly impacts how you setup and integrate your system.
  • A new FA (3) schema version for electronic invoice formatting is introduced.
  • The authentication method based on token will be phased out by 2026. As a result, SAP will support only certificate-based authentication for KSeF 2.0 (only tokens were supported for KSeF 1.0).

You can already setup your business system for the new invoice format required with KSef 2.0 and update the integration requirements to use SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition. 

For now, you can connect with the KSeF 2.0 test environment, that is, the sandbox environment that allows you to test the integration with KSeF, to exchange electronic customer invoices if you use SAP ERP, SAP S/4HANA or SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. This test connection does not require authentication with real token or certificate.

Please note that the steps described in this blog post are only valid for the test environment of KSeF 2.0 and should be implemented in your test environment only. Existing integration remains applicable for production environment of KSeF 1.0 until the legal mandate comes into effect, at the end of January 2026. You can expect a subsequent post with details about the pre-production and production environments of KSeF 2.0, and also what to do when KSeF system is unavailable.

Be aware that KSeF has different environments that should be assigned to different service plans of the cloud edition, as follows:

  • KSeF 2.0 Test Environment - Test Plan of the cloud edition
  • KSeF 2.0 Demo (Pre-Prod) Environment - Test Plan of the cloud edition
  • KSeF 2.0 Production Environment: Standard Plan of the cloud edition

 

Depending on when you integrated your business system with the cloud edition, the steps to setup your system for KSeF 2.0 can vary. Before starting, make sure the E-Invoices Through KSeF (PL) process is active in the Activate Processes app - the process that should be activated is the same if you configured your system for KSeF 1.0 (in this case, it is already active), or if you are configuring your system for KSeF 2.0 now.

For the integration, you need to perform the general integration settings. For that, consider according to your business system: 

  • Integrating All Other Processes and Countries/Regions with SAP ERP 
  • Integrating All Other Processes and Countries/Regions with SAP S/4HANA or SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 

Please, also consider the following:

  • You should perform all the steps described under the Establishing Connection from Cloud Edition to Business System section, including configuring the Cloud Connector. This is a technical prerequisite and does not require additional license.
  • If you use processes other than Peppol Exchange, Argentina, Romania, Serbia, or Slovakia, you might have done these steps already and there are no additional steps for now.
  • If you have onboarded the cloud edition after April 2023, you donâ€™t need to create a new service binding when performing the steps for the new integration. 
  • Once these settings are completed, the system automatically sets the integration with KSeF 2.0.

For all scenarios listed, no process-specific configuration is required as the authentication with the test environment does not require a real certificate.

If you have configured your system for KSeF 1.0, you have already made process-specific configuration using your NIP number. The system ignores that configuration, but you can also delete it, if you prefer. For KSeF 2.0, new process-specific configuration will be made available soon.

Besides the integration with the cloud edition, there are steps that you have to perform in your business systems related to the new invoice format, as follows:

  • Implement SAP Note 367668.
  • Do the configuration to adapt your business system to the legal mandate. For more information, see:
    • SAP S/4HANA or SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition  
    • SAP ERP

Even if you already implemented KSeF 1.0, please review the complete Customizing section, as new configuration nodes and new configuration values have been introduced with KSeF 2.0.

  • In the Define Process Communication Through Cloud Services Customizing activity, update the Service option to Cloud Edition: Standard Integration. 

For more information, you can access the Regulatory Change Manager for Mandatory e-Invoicing through KSeF in Poland. 

Best regards,

entry.title: CPI HTTP Receiver always returns 400 â€œSyntax Errorâ€ although same JSON works in Postman
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,

We are trying to call a BZSt REST endpoint from SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) using the HTTP Receiver adapter. The goal is to send a small JSON request from our SAP backend to the German EVATR service and receive a validation response.

The same request (same URL, same JSON body, same token/parameters) works perfectly in Postman. In CPI, however, we consistently receive an HTTP 400 error from the target system.

The error message in the CPI log is:

org.apache.camel.component.ahc.AhcOperationFailedException:
HTTP operation failed invoking https://api.evatr.vies.bzst.de/app/v1/abfrage with statusCode: 400

 The response body from the server is an HTML error page:

<html>
<head>
<base href="/error_path/">
<title>400 Bad Request</title>
</head>
<body>
<h1>Bad Request</h1>
<p>The server detected a syntax error in your request.<br>
Check your request and all parameters.</p>

<p>Your request ID was: aSW1_biQek9iXbaem_MTxwAABZY</p>
</body>
</html>

In the meantime, we have tested quite a lot of variations. We tried many different header combinations, including explicitly setting headers like Content-Type, Accept, Host, and Content-Length, and we experimented with the â€œAllowed / Request Headersâ€ setting of the HTTP Receiver adapter (including using *). None of these attempts changed the behavior â€“ CPI still only seems to forward a very small set of headers, and additional headers set via a Content Modifier often do not appear in the actual outbound call (according to the HTTP_Receiver_Adapter_Request_Headers attachment).

We also experimented with the payload itself: different JSON formats, slightly modified test payloads, sending the exact same body as Postman, and even building a minimal iFlow where the JSON body is hard-coded in a Content Modifier and sent directly to the HTTP receiver. The result is always the same 400 response from the BZSt service, so it does not appear to be a simple syntax issue in the JSON itself.

What could be the reason for this behavior, and does anyone know how to resolve it or what else we should check?

Here is how the iFlow is built and the error messages:

entry.title: How to handle the exception CX_RAP_HANDLER_NOT_IMPLEMENTED with the reason Handler not implemented;
entry.content:
Today I tried to import a RAP BO using abapGIT. The import of the repository ran into errors and thus not all objects were activated.  

I did some fixes and activated several (but accidentily not all ðŸ˜‰) objects including the service binding.

When trying to create a new entity I received the following error analyis in the dump.

Error analysis

The program has indicated exception "CX_SADL_DUMP_APPL_MODEL_ERROR" as the reason for the
termination:
Processing was aborted because of an application modeling error: See previous in exception chain.
The exception is related to the previous exception "CX_RAP_HANDLER_NOT_IMPLEMENTED" that occurred in
program "CL_RAP_BHV_PROCESSOR==========CP", in line 30 of include "CL_RAP_BHV_PROCESSOR==========CM01G". The reason for this exception
